title: Best RX 7600 XT graphics card 2024: we rank the different AIB variants
text: Home » GPU » GPU Guide » Best RX 7600 XT graphics card 2024: we rank the different AIB variants We breakdown the features, pros, and cons of the AMD Radeon RX 7600 XT GPU models currently available to buy WePC is reader-supported. When you buy through links on our site, we may earn an affiliate commission. Prices subject to change. Learn more The latest AMD Radeon card is here: we’ve listed below the best RX 7600 XT graphics card models currently available, discussing the pros and cons of each in relative terms, to help you pick which AIB is right for you and your build. The new GPU looks to be an interesting contender for mid-range builds, be they sole gaming machines or creative workstations. You can read our RX 7600 XT vs RX 7600 piece to see how it compares against its predecessor, and please do take a gander at our where to buy RX 7600 XT guide to find the best place to buy pick one up in your part of the world. Further useful information for your new build can also be found in our best CPU for RX 7600 XT, best PSU, and best motherboard for RX 7600 XT pages. Shop on Amazon Shop on Amazon Shop on Amazon The below list represents our top picks as the market currently stands. As new AIBs are released and further testing on them takes place, this list will be subject to change. Core clock speed 2,810MHz boost, 1,720MHz base Streaming processors 2,048 Memory 16GB GDDR6 Dimensions ‎11.93 x 4.53 x 0.04 inches PSU required 600W TBP 190W At the top of the selection is the XFX Speedster QICK309, providing a great choice for the graphics card in general. As the board power increases between the 7600 XT vs 7600, the cooling on the XFX comes to improve it. Keeping things elegant and simple it has a slim if a bit long design to it. It keeps things clean and optimizes airflow with three fans on its model. It also has a flow-through design as well as open sides to allow for the hot air to escape. It has a four-piece heatpipe for moving all the heat away from the processor itself and allowing the processor’s clocks to keep on a higher level. It also comes with a dual BIOS for ease of use and plenty of flexibility into which mode you want to use it in. Core clock speed 2,801MHz boost, 1,720MHz base Streaming processors 2,048 Memory 16GB GDDR6 Dimensions 227.2 x 123.24 x 49.6 mm PSU required 600W TBP 190W For a more compact option, the ASUS Dual RX 7600 XT is the one to go for. Knocking things down to a smaller dimension, it also only utilizes one power connector so you can keep things cleaner. But it still comes with a great overclock that provides a good performance improvement over more base-level cards. It does keep things down to only two axial tech fans to keep the temperature under wraps, they come with rings to keep the airflow going where it should. Whilst it might not have a flow-through design, it does come in a t 2.5slots so takes up more space with its heatsink to still be an effective solution and keep your performance going. Core clock speed 2810MHz boost, 2539MHz game Streaming processors 2,048 Memory 16GB GDDR6 Dimensions 281.4 x 116.6 x 52.6 mm PSU required 600W TBP 190W Gigabyte can keep things big and simple. With a thick Windoforce cooling system, it has three 80mm fans that counter-spin and five composite heat pipes on the processor, so you can be sure to get a great cooling capacity on the GPU. The air has a lot of areas to leave through as the back plate has a cut out for it to go through along with an open area around the sides. There is also a simple RGB logo on the side that can be controlled for a bit of flair, whilst the rest of the card keeps things simple and stylish. It provides a great quality for the cost it asks and allows you a great choice of RX 7600 XT. Typically AMD doesn’t actually release Founder’s Editions of their graphics cards that are available to the public. They produce a reference model that is used for their own testing and benchmarks and which is sent out to manufacturers to aid them, however, the ones that actually hit the retail market are the AIB versions made by these third-party manufacturers. AMD usually quotes the prices for its products with a SEP (Single Exit Price) figure, however, given that RX 7600 XT Founder’s Edition GPUs aren’t really available, this is only some guidance as to how much the various AIBs will cost. We know that AMD has given the SEP value for the RX 7600 XT as $329 USD, and we’ve seen an XFX Speedster on Amazon sell for $369.99. Assuming that the SEP is the likely minimum value then, we can estimate a price range of roughly $330 – $400 USD for the various different variants. Although the AMD Radeon RX 7600 XT release date and release time have already come to pass, we haven’t yet seen many variants listed online. Hopefully, more AIBs will be listed on Amazon, etc. in the coming days. That being said, we don’t anticipate stock issues for the models that are up and available to buy. We trust you are now well-versed in what the best RX 7600 XT is for your needs. Do take a gander at our primary best GPU page if you’re interested in all graphics card models across all brands, or our best AMD GPU page if you’re dedicated to a Radeon-only rig.
